results.title: The Fly = A Legy
results.brief_description: Creatively animated in sepia print, this Academy Award winnning short provides a fly’s eye view of the world. Sensing the approach of autumn, the fly, hoping for safety, takes shelter in a house. Without commentary, sound effects only. Award: AMPAS 1980 Academy Award for Best Animated Short Subject. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Classical Hollywood style
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, Molly Ornati, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “American cinema”.
In classical Hollywood film, the story is primary. Filmmakers rely on style, structure, narrative and visual elements to tell their story. Martin Scorcese and Sydney Pollack are among the directors who discuss their own style and how the classical Hollywood style, although evolving, endures and impacts on their work.

results.brief_description: A series which groups sections of the Bible into meaningful areas. Based on the Lion Story Bible by Penny Frank.

results.title: Thinking and writing about film
results.creator_credit: Richard Smigielski, Brian Street, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “American cinema”.
Provides a formal and cultural analysis of a classical film sequence serving as a critical how-to guide for those new to film critique.

results.title: The Flower and the hive
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Larry Gosnell, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film showing the relationship between the activity of honey bees and the fertility of field and orchard crops. The process of cross-pollination of flowers by bees is observed in close-up. The life of the hive is similarly illustrated, including the curious dance by which a bee communicates the discovery of a new source of nectar to the colony in the hive .
results.creator_credit_for_label: J.V. Durden, Larry Gosnell, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Classical Hollywood style today
results.creator_credit: Greg Martinelli, Lorna Thomas, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “American cinema”.
This program offers interviews with contemporary directors, European film-makers, scholars, critics and studio-era veterans who probe Hollywood’s influence on both American and world culture.

results.title: The Floating Brothel
results.creator_credit: Mark Lewis, Sonja Armstrong, Essential Viewing, Film Australia and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Based on the 2001 book of the same name by Sian Rees, “The Floating Brothel” tells the story of some of the women transported to Australia on the convict ship The Lady Juliana in 1789. As well as punishment, transportation of the women was supposed to supply the fledgling penal colony with sexual partners for the men already there, with the London Colonial Office ordering the women’s keepers to “promote a matrimonial connection to improve morals and secure settlement”. In the film, the stories of some of the women aboard The Lady Juliana - their backgrounds, their crimes, their journey, their fates in and effects upon the colony - are revealed to three of their modern-day descendants; Australian women who find out more than they bargained for about their convict ancestors. Narrated by Wendy Hughes.

results.title: The Combat film
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Pitkethly, Danielle Gardner, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “American cinema”.
Beginning with World War II combat films which were produced under U.S. Federal Government directives, this program examines the role of the combat film in filling a social and political need. Critics and directors describe the evolution of these films, the rise of the Vietnam film and the influence of newsreel documentaries and television news on the genre.

results.title: The Western
results.creator_credit: Lesley Karsten, Sasha Alpert, BBC, KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.) and New York Center for Visual History
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “American cinema”.
The Western is an American myth that has been translated by other cultures and re-interpreted time and time again but never dies. With film clips and critical commentary on Westerns, from John Ford’s “Stagecoach” to the work of Arthur Penn, Sam Peckinpah and Clint Eastwood, the program traces the aesthetic evolution of the genre as well as its sociological importance.

results.title: The Five faces of Kadarwati = Kadarwati
results.creator_credit: Sophan Sophiaan, J. Adisubrata and Gramedia Film
results.brief_description: A melodrama about the oppression of women during the Japanese occupation in Southeast Asia. Leaving for Singapore thinking she is being sent to medical school by the Japanese, Kadarwati arrives only to find she has been picked to serve the Japanese soldiers stationed there. When she finally meets a Japanese officer who is kind to her and with whom she falls in love, he leaves her behind by committing harakiri. After being subject to abuses and torture by Japanese soldiers, she is brought back home to Java where she plots revenge - changing her name and becoming a prostitute at Japanese headquarters. Directed by Sophan Sophiaan, who became a politician and member of Megawati Sukarnoputri’s PDI-P. In Indonesian with English subtitles.
